objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.pubplace: LondonThe place of publication is not recorded in the volume, but Blake was living in London at the time of its composition, etching, and printing.

objinfo.printdate: c. 1811Most of the plates (Objects 4-10, 12-26) were printed in black ink c. 1811. Object 1, printed in green ink, may have been printed and colored as early as 1789. Object 1 was added to copy S by the London dealer Bernard Quaritch between 1920 and 1922 (see the Note on Provenance, below). The plates in shades of brown ink (Objects 2, 3, 11, 27, 28) are probably also remainders from earlier printings, probably c. 1794-1795.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 12.3 x 7.7 cm. and 10.9 x 6.3 cm.
objinfo.leafsize: ranging between 19.1 x 13.7 cm. and 20.7 x 15.2 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching, with some white-line etching, and hand coloringObject 2, the title page, includes small amounts of green color printing on foliage. Blake may have added shell gold (powdered gold mixed with gum or glue) to a few plates to create highlights.
objinfo.inkcolor: green (Object 1), brown (Objects 2, 11, 27, 28), reddish brown (Object 3), and black (Objects 4-10, 12-26)
objinfo.watermark: J WHATMAN | 1808The watermark appears only in the leaves of Objects 8 and 25 (Bentley Plates 9 and 25).
objinfo.pennednumbers: Objects 2-28 numbered 2-28 top right in pen and ink
objinfo.framelines: 1Most plates have a thin border line, probably executed in pen and ink, contiguous with the edges of the plates.
objinfo.binding: disboundFormerly hinged on larger leaves and bound in brown morocco by Riviere and Son.
objinfo.stabholes: Objects 2-28 were originally stabbed through three holes, 6.2 cm. from the top and 2.8 and 2.8 cm. apart. Object 1, added to copy S by the London dealer Bernard Quaritch between 1920 and 1922 (see the Note on Provenance, below), was originally stabbed through three holes, 5.6 cm. from the top and 3.9 and 4.2 cm. apart.

provenance.name: Cincinnati Art Museum
provenance.note: Possibly the copy acquired by Thomas Frognall Dibdin no later than 1816; offered by the London dealer Bernard Quaritch, Dec. 1920 catalogue 361, item 118, "frontispiece [Object 1] is missing from this copy" (£350), and March 1922 catalogue 368, item 107, the frontispiece (Object 1) now listed as present (£400); Phoebe A. D. Boyle, sold from her collection by the executors of her estate, Anderson Galleries, New York, 19 Nov. 1923, lot 46 ($1100 to the dealer George D. Smith, probably acting for the collector George C. Smith); G. C. Smith no later than 1927; sold from G. C. Smith collection, Parke-Bernet Galleries, New York, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 16 ($2300 to the dealer James Gannon); "sold about 1941 by [the New York dealer] Scribner's to Albert Rouillier Galleries of Chicago" (according to Harold E. Graves of Scribner's—see Bentley page 411); Herbert Greer French, who bequeathed the book to the Cincinnati Art Museum in 1942; accessioned by the Museum in 1943.

desc.objtitle:
Frontispiece to Songs of Innocence Songs of Innocence,
Object 1 (Bentley 2, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

objnote.p: This frontispiece plate was added to copy S by the London dealer Bernard Quaritch between 1920 and 1922; see the note on Provenance on the Copy Information page. This leaf is badly stained, as though exposed to the elements for many years and badly treated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired partly nude male in semi-transparent tights, holding a musical pipe, walks toward the viewer with his left leg forward. This shepherd-piper looks up to the right at a cherubic nude male infant or child floating in a horizontal position on a cloud. The child, with his arms raised horizontally and his legs spread, looks down at the piper. The plate is framed by trees on both sides whose leafy branches arch across the top. Behind the piper are grazing sheep and, in the background, more trees. Dark shadows fall across the ground left of the shepherd.

component.illusobjdesc: Dark shadows cover a good deal of the ground left of the shepherd's feet.

A curly-haired partly nude male in semi-transparent tights, holding a musical pipe, strides toward the viewer with his left leg forward. His left arm is bent at the elbow. The body of this shepherd-piper faces forward but he looks up to the right at a cherubic male child.

A muscular but cherubic nude male infant or child with short hair hovers in a horizontal position on a cloud above the head of a shepherd-piper. The child, with his arms raised horizontally and his legs spread, looks down at the piper.
A cherubic male child hovers on a cloud above the shepherd-piper's head. Very slight rose tinting on the cloud might hint at a sunrise or sunset.
A flock of sheep grazes behind the shepherd-piper. Two in the front have their heads down.

Trees frame the plate on both sides. The tree on the left has a single trunk, while the two trees on the right intertwine. Their leafy branches form an arch overhead. There are more leafy trees in the background.
A male shepherd holds a musical pipe.

desc.objtitle:
Title Page,
Object 2 (Bentley 3, Erdman 3, Keynes 3)

objnote.p: Green color printing appears on the leaves and a few branches of the tree.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a boy with curly hair; the child on the right, with long hair, is probably a girl. To the right of the group is a large apple(?) tree bearing fruit; around the trunk loosely spirals a vine. Various small figures can be seen among the letters of the title, including a piper wearing a broad-brimmed hat standing in the crook of the first letter of "Innocence." Birds fly in the sky beneath and to the left of the "S" and above the "N" in "SONGS." Another bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence."

component.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds a book that two children read.
In her lap a nurse or mother holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a male with curly hair looking down at the book.

In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the right, with long hair and wearing a gown, is probably a girl. Her left arm is bent at the elbow, with the forearm raised horizontally. Her left hand may be pointing to a passage in the book.
In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read.
A nurse(?) sits in a chair that faces right.

To the right of the nurse(?) and two children is a large apple(?) tree, bearing fruit (around "of" in the title); around its trunk loosely spirals a vine. The upper leaves on the right of the tree reach near the flame-like vegetative motifs springing from the letters of "SONGS" (leafy extensions of the initial "S," the "N," and the terminal "S" are particularly extravagant).
Though more distinct in other copies, there may be a tree on the horizon, just right of the trunk of the large tree.
In the "O" of "SONGS" is a kneeling figure with arms raised in a curve at about 135 degrees.
A tiny form, standing above the left vertical of the "N" of "SONGS," might be a figure with arms raised at 45 degrees. This figure may wear a hat.
A standing figure, perhaps with a wing (lightly printed in this copy) leans against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS." The figure may be looking down at and holding a book, reading or writing.
The figure leaning against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS" may be holding a book.
A small gowned(?) female(?) figure with both arms raised vertically stands, facing left and twisting away from the viewer, in the "G" of "SONGS."
A male piper(?) with a broad-brimmed hat and holding a pipe to his mouth, stands facing left and leaning against the "I" of "Innocence."
A bird flies in the sky beneath and to the left of the "S" in "SONGS."
A bird flies on extended wings above the "N" of "SONGS."
A bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence."
The background coloring of the plate indicates sky at sunrise or sunset. There may be low hills in the landscape.
Although more pronounced in other copies, shadows cover the ground on each side of the tree.
The coloring of the landscape suggests some sort of vegetation, perhaps grass in the foreground.

lg.l: SONGS
of
Innocence
The Author & Printer WBlake

desc.objtitle:
Introduction,
Object 3 (Bentley 4, Erdman 4, Keynes 4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels (top left to bottom right): (1) two figures, the front one gowned and seated, the back figure possibly seated also; (2) a running, leaping, nude(?) figure; (3) a standing figure, looking down and possibly with a bird flying overhead; (4) an indistinct figure, possibly looking down at a cradle; (5) at top right, a flying bird with vegetation, perhaps tree limbs and leaves, above and below; (6) a seated figure facing the viewer with legs crossed and drawn up to the body; (7) a solitary standing figure with three flying birds; (8) possibly a seated figure with prominent knees drawn up and vegetation above. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas. Washes behind the text suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins leafy vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils, some of them (top, bottom) loopy, that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas.

In the panel at top left there are two indistinct figures. The one in the foreground is gowned, seated, and facing right. The smaller figure to the right may be a standing child or a seated adult, again gowned.
In the second panel down from top left, a nude figure runs or leaps toward us with legs spread and arms raised to 135 degrees.
In the third panel down from top left is a standing figure with head lowered and perhaps a bird flying overhead. The human figure may be indulging in some sort of agricultural activity.
In the third panel down from top left is a standing figure with head lowered and perhaps a bird flying overhead.
There may be a standing figure in the panel lowest on the left, possibly looking down at a cradle.
There may be hooded cradle below and to the left of the standing figure(?) in the panel lowest on the left.
In the panel at top right is a bird flying with vegetation, perhaps the leafy branches of a tree, above and below.
In the panel at top right is a bird flying with vegetation, perhaps the leafy branches of a tree, above and below.
In the second panel from top right is a seated figure facing the viewer with legs crossed and drawn up to the body.

In the third panel from top right is a solitary standing figure, who may wear a gown and indulge in some sort of agricultural activity, with three birds flying near. The figure's left arm may be raised at just under 45 degrees.
Though indistinct in this copy, there may be a seated figure in the lowest panel on the right, with legs drawn up and knees prominent.
The upper portion of the lowest panel on the right appears to be filled with vegetation of some sort.
Washes behind the text suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset. Brown washes just above the lower margin suggest bare earth.

lg.l: Piping down the valleys wild
Piping songs of pleasant glee
On a cloud I saw a child.
And he laughing said to me.
Pipe a song about a Lamb;
So I piped with merry chear,
Piper pipe that song again__
So I piped, he wept to hear.
Drop thy pipe thy happy pipe
Sing thy songs of happy chear,
So I sung the same again
While he wept with joy to hear
Piper sit thee down and write
In a book that all may read__
So he vanish'd from my sight.
And I pluck'd a hollow reed.
And I made a rural pen,
And I stain'd the water clear,
And I wrote my happy songs,
Every child may joy to hear

desc.objtitle:
The Shepherd,
Object 4 (Bentley 5, Erdman 5, Keynes 5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young, curly-haired male shepherd in tights stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep. He holds a crook in his left hand; his shepherd's purse, or wallet, is visible near his right knee. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks forward and beside it another sheep lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees and perhaps a hilltop in the background, where the washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset. On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends. Three smaller birds soar to the right of the large bird. Two additional birds perch on the bare section of the branch below and to the right of the three flying birds.

component.illusobjdesc: A young male shepherd with short, curly hair wears tights and stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep—perhaps looking at the sheep that lifts its head toward him. He holds a crook in his left hand; his purse is visible near his right knee. His arms are bent at the elbow, with his body facing forward but his head turned to the left.

A shepherd watches his grazing flock of sheep. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks straight ahead and beside it another sheep—possibly one of the "lambs" of line 7—lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. Although two sheep in the middle of the flock may also have raised heads, the majority of the grazing sheep appear to have their heads lowered to the ground, including the ram and several others in front.

Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with blossoms near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees in the background.
The coloring of the ground indicates grass.
Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms near the bottom.
There are more trees and possibly a hilltop in the background. A slight shadow covers the ground on the left.
Washes above the trees in the background suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends in the sky. Three much smaller birds soar to the right of the large one. Two additional birds perch on the bare section of the branch below and to the right of the three flying birds.
The shepherd's purse is visible beside his right knee.
The shepherd holds a crook.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves branches off the "T" in "The" in the title.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves branches off the "T" in "The" in the title.

lg.l: How sweet is the Shepherds sweet lot,
From the morn to the evening he strays;
He shall follow his sheep all the day
And his tongue shall be filled with praise.
For he hears the lambs innocent call,The "s" of "hears" did not print clearly in copy S.
And he hears the ewes tender reply,
He is watchful while they are in peace.
For they know when their Shepherd is nigh.

desc.objtitle:
The Ecchoing Green The Echoing Green,
Object 5 (Bentley 6, Erdman 6, Keynes 6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A group of four adults—the text mentions "old folk" (Object 5, line 16) and "mothers" (Object 6, line 12)—including two(?) adults on the left, both wearing brimmed hats, and two females wearing a scarf over her head (center) or a cap (right) sit presumably on a circular bench at the base of the trunk of a large oak tree. They superintend five young children who stand at their knees. Behind them five older children play and stroll on a grassy area. The dense, umbrella-shaped canopy of the central tree spreads over the entire scene from margin to margin. Other trees or bushes fill the background. The shadows along the lower edge of the design suggest that the time is late afternoon or early evening ("the darkening Green" of line 17 on the following object).

component.illusobjdesc: On the left end of a bench at the base of the central tree sit two adults. The adult furthest to the left seems to be wearing a long gown. He(?) may have long hair and may be among the "old folk" (line 16). His left arm is at his side and rests in his lap; he may look down toward the child standing at his knees.

On the left end of a bench at the base of the central tree sit two adults. The second adult from the left, hands on his knees, left leg forward, seems to be looking toward the children playing to the left behind the tree. His hat and knee breeches are visible. Long-haired, he may be among the "old folk"(line 16).
A small child with short hair(?) who may be gowned stands at the knees of the first adult sitting on the left side of the tree trunk and looks up at him.

Two females in full gowns—nurses or the "mothers" (Object 6, line 12) mentioned in the text—sit on a bench at the base of a large oak tree. There are two children standing in front of the woman in the center, one at each knee. Her right arm rests on the back of, and perhaps holds, the child at the left. She wears a scarf over her head and faces forward, but with her head twisted to the right.
Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated directly in front of an oak tree. The child on the left, in a gown, lays its head in her lap, face toward the viewer, and may be sleeping.

Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated directly in front of an oak tree. The child on the right, short-haired, clothed in tights(?) and probably male, reaches up with his right hand and rests his left on her knee. He is facing away from the viewer.

Two females in full gowns—nurses or the "mothers" (Object 6, line 12) mentioned in the text—sit on a bench at the base of a large oak tree. The woman on the right holds a child, to whom she may be looking. Another child stands at her left knee. She may be wearing a cap.

A child stands at the left knee of a woman seated on the right side of the group under the oak tree. This child faces forward, looking slightly right, and rests its arm on the left knee of the seated woman.
A child lies, possibly sleeping, in the lap of the woman on the right beneath the tree. Only the head and extended left arm of this child are visible. She or he may be holding onto the woman.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. Left of the tree trunk two male children wearing shirts and knee breeches play an unidentified ball game(?). The child at far left, who faces away from the viewer, stands with his legs spread, his right arm at his side, and holds a bat(?) with his raised left hand. A ball is pictured between his head and the bat.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. Left of the tree trunk two male children wearing shirts and knee breeches play an unidentified ball game(?). The short-haired child second from left, who faces the viewer, stands or leaps with his legs spread, his arms raised horizontally and palms up or facing the viewer.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. At far right two children—the nearest one dressed as a male in tights—walk together, facing left. The front-most youth holds his bent left arm at his side.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. At far right two adolescents walk together, facing left. The features of the child back and furthest right are indistinct, but he or she may wear tights or a short gown and have long hair.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. To the right of the tree trunk stands a short-haired(?) child, arms at his(?) side, who may be playing a ball game with the two standing children to the left of the trunk. He may be wearing tights and a shirt.

The thick-leaved, umbrella-shaped canopy of the central tree spreads over the entire scene from margin to margin. Other trees or bushes fill the background. The lower reaches of this background vegetation may form a hedge.
The child at the far left holds a bat(?) in his upraised left hand. A ball appears between the bat and his head.

The shadows just above the lower margin of the image suggest that the time is late afternoon or early evening ("the darkening Green" of line 17 on the following object). Washes above the background vegetation also suggest sky at sunset.
A large grassy area—the "darkening Green" of line 17 on the following object—spreads beneath and behind the central oak tree.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the left, dressed in a shirt and breeches, stands erect, holding a bat by his side with his right hand while his left hand is hidden behind him. The one on the right, also dressed in a shirt and knee breeches, runs behind a large hoop that he rolls with a stick in his right hand. Leafy grapevines, rooted at the bottom of the plate, flourish to the left and right of the text, and the space between the stanzas is filled with a tendril from the vine on the right, which also bears a cluster of grapes to the right of the second stanza along with several blossoms and leaves. The title of the poem is decorated with lively vegetation. A vine sprouts from the initial "T" in the title and the final "n" sends out buds and blossoms that surround the head of the boy beneath. A bird with outspread wings and forked tail flies to the right of the grapes. The background tinting suggests a sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the left, short-haired, dressed in a shirt and breeches, stands erect in contrapposto, holding a bat by his side with his right hand while his left hand is hidden behind him. He faces forward but looks up and to the right.
Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the right, curly-haired, dressed in a shirt and knee breeches, runs behind a large hoop that he rolls to the right with a stick in his right hand.

Leafy grapevines, rooted at the bottom of the plate, flourish to the left and right of the text, and the space between the stanzas is filled with a loopy tendril from the vine on the right, which also bears a cluster of grapes to the right of the second stanza along with several blossoms and leaves. The title of the poem is decorated with lively vegetation. A vine sprouts from the initial "T" in the title and the final "n" sends out buds and blossoms that surround the head of the boy beneath.
The boy on the left holds a bat by his side.
A bird with outspread wings and forked tail flies to the right of the grapes.
The background tinting of the text area suggest a sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: The Sun does arise,
And make happy the skies.
The merry bells ring
To welcome the Spring.
The sky-lark and thrush.
The birds of the bush,
Sing louder around,
To the bells chearful sound.
While our sports shall be seen
On the Ecchoing Green.
Old John with white hair
Does laugh away care,
Sitting under the oak,
Among the old folk,

desc.objtitle:
The Ecchoing Green (continued) The echoing Green (continued),
Object 6 (Bentley 7, Erdman 7, Keynes 7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a background colored to suggest a sunset on the "darkening Green" (line 17), a procession of nine adults and children (including one infant) in a variety of positions moves generally leftward. Overhead in the branches of two intertwining grape vines that are rooted at lower right and grow upward along the right margin and left to embrace the stanzas of the poem, one boy, left, stretches on tiptoe to reach a cluster of grapes on the left while a second boy, right, hands another cluster to a girl who reaches up from the grass below. Next to her, walking left, is a long-haired male in hat and tights; he holds a bunch of grapes in his extended left hand. Next in line is a woman who looks down at the infant in her arms. A small child stands just to the left. In the center, the tallest figure in the group, perhaps "Old John with white hair" (line 12, Object 5), points forward with his right hand. A boy to the left, who faces away from the viewer, holds a bat at his side with his left hand. At the front of the procession are a boy and girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. Between them is a kite that the girl may be holding. The green tinting of the ground below the playful procession suggests grass.

component.illusobjdesc: Standing on a branch of a luxuriant grapevine, a short-haired boy with his head bent back, seen in profile, stretches on tiptoe to reach a cluster of grapes with his upraised right arm. He appears to wear tights.

Lying on a branch of a luxuriant grape vine, a curly-haired boy in tights hands a cluster of grapes down to a girl on the grass below. He may be holding the vine with his left hand. His right leg is bent at the knee. His body faces forward with his head turned part-way to the left.

A girl in a full gown and a hat that resembles a halo reaches up with her left hand to take a cluster of grapes from a boy lying on the grapevine above her. At least her left foot is on tiptoe. She looks up toward the grapes.

Walking left among the lower group of figures, second from right, is a long-haired youthful male in brimmed hat and tights. He holds a bunch of grapes in his extended left hand. His left foot is forward.
Among the lower group of figures, third from the right, stands (or walks) a woman in a full gown who looks down at the infant in her arms. She faces left. Her hair seems to be pulled back in a bun.

Among the lower group of figures, fourth from the right and crowded between two larger adults, stands or walks a small boy in tights who faces forward but looks up toward the woman and infant to the right.
There is an infant in the arms of the woman third from the right among the lower group of figures.

In the center of the lower group of figures, the tallest figure, with long hair, brimmed hat, and dressed in coat and knee breeches—perhaps "Old John with white hair"—points forward with his right hand. His left arm is at his side, but may be reaching down to the boy holding a bat.

Among the lower group of figures, third from the left, facing away from the viewer, stands (in a contrapposto posture) or walks a short-haired boy in tights who holds a bat in his extended left hand. His right arm is bent at the elbow.

At the front of the procession of figures are a boy, with curly hair and wearing tights, and a girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. His arms are at his side; his head and shoulders are silhouetted against the kite behind him.

At the front of the procession of figures are a boy and girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. Between them is a kite that she may be holding. She is long-haired and wears a gown; she appears to stand on tiptoe.

A luxuriant grapevine, or rather two vines intertwined, are rooted at lower right and grow upward along the right margin. One vine continues up the right margin, while the other branches left to embrace the stanzas of the poem. There are leaves here and there on the vines, a grape cluster at the upper left, over the head of a boy who stretches to pick them, a second cluster beside the head of the boy in the branches on the right, and a third in his hand. There is also a bunch of grapes in the extended left hand of the boy walking to the left, second figure from the right. Green tinting on the ground below the parade of figures suggests grass.
There are two children's toys in the lower procession of figures: a kite between the boy and girl on the left, and a bat held by the boy to the right of them.
The area behind the lower procession of figures is colored to suggest sky at sunset—the "darkening Green" (line 17) of the text.

lg.l: They laugh at our play,
And soon they all say,
Such such were the joys.
When we all girls & boys,
In our youth-time were seen,
On the Ecchoing Green.
Till the little ones weary
No more can be merry
The sun does descend,
And our sports have an end;
Round the laps of their mothers.
Many sisters and brothers,
Like birds in their nest,
Are ready for rest:
And sport no more seen,
On the darkening Green.

desc.objtitle:
The Lamb,
Object 7 (Bentley 8, Erdman 8, Keynes 8)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a grassy landscape, a nude boy with short hair stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep—some grazing, some standing, some lying down. The boy reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "little lamb" of the text—with his hands. Behind the flock are a leafy oak tree with a large trunk (left) and a cottage or barn (right) with a doorway or window. On its thatched roof perch two birds, often identified as doves. Two slender trees, one on each side, frame the plate. Both trees are intertwined with vines that sprout leaves, blossoms, and several loopy tendrils. Where the tree branches meet and intertwine at the top, creating an arch between the title and the text of the poem, they are leafy. Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas. Background washes suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: In a grassy landscape, a nude boy with short hair stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep. He reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands.

In a grassy landscape, a nude boy stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep—some grazing, some standing, some lying down. The boy reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands.
The green coloring on the ground suggests grass.
A dark shadow covers the ground between the leftmost tree and the nearby flock of sleep.
Behind the flock of sheep is a leafy oak tree with a large trunk (left).

Two slender trees, one on each side, frame the plate. Both trees are intertwined with vines that sprout several loopy tendrils. Where the tree branches meet and intertwine at the top, creating an arch between the title and the text of the poem, they are leafy. Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.
On the roof of a cottage or barn perch two birds, often identified as doves.
Behind the flock of sheep is a cottage or barn (right) with a thatched(?) roof and a window. A small shadow darkens the top left corner of the window.
Background washes above the design and behind the text suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.

lg.l: Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Gave thee life & bid thee feed.
By the stream & o'er the mead;
Gave thee clothing of delight,
Softest clothing wooly bright;
Gave thee such a tender voice,
Making all the vales rejoice;
Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Little Lamb I'll tell thee,
Little Lamb Ill tell thee;
He is called by thy name,
For he calls himself a Lamb;
He is meek & he is mild,
He became a little child:
I a child & thou a lamb,
We are called by his name.
Little Lamb God bless thee,
Little Lamb God bless thee.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Black Boy,
Object 8 (Bentley 9, Erdman 9, Keynes 9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At dawn, an adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child who points upward with his left hand. With her right hand she reaches across her lap toward the boy. Presumably they correspond to the "mother" (lines 3, 7) and "Little Black Boy" (title) of the text. They are both dark of skin. The pair sits under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother. A vine twines upward around the tree trunk on the left. A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller, grows up the right margin and arches over the sun. A grassy, hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon. "The rising sun" of the text (line 11) mounts above the horizon in a sky tinged with rose washes.

component.illusobjdesc: Under a tree, a dark-skinned adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child. With her right hand she reaches across her lap toward the boy. Presumably she corresponds to the "mother" (lines 3, 7) of the text.

Under a tree, an adult female sits facing a kneeling(?) child, apparently nude and male with short hair, who points upward with his left hand. Presumably he is the "Little Black Boy" of the text. They are both dark of skin.
The mother and child sit under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother. A vine twines upward around the tree trunk.
"The rising sun" of the text (line 11) mounts above the horizon in a sky tinged with rose and blue.
A small shadow, presumably cast by the tree at left, darkens the grass in front of the mother and child.
A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller than the one on the left, grows up the right margin and arches over the rising sun.
A grassy, hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon.
A grassy, hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the bottom left, a pair of intertwined vines grows up the left margin and around the words of the title. From the same point at lower left, a third vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above the lower margin, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below line 13 of the text. Another vine with loops and leaves fills the right margin above. The capital letters of the title are ornamented to harmonize with the vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black." A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 7, after "tree." Background washes suggest the sky at dawn, as in the vignette above.

component.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the bottom left, a pair of intertwined vines grows up the left margin and around the words of the title. From the same point at lower left, a third vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above its bottom margin, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below the end of line 13. One extension of this vine descends in a spiral in the plate's lower right corner. Above, another vine with loops and leaves fills the remaining spaces right of the text. The capital letters of the title are ornamented to harmonize with the vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black."
A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 7, after "tree."
Background washes suggest the sky at dawn, as in the vignette above.

lg.l: My mother bore me in the southern wild,
And I am black, but O! my soul is white.
White as an angel is the English child:
But I am black as if bereav'd of light.
My mother taught me underneath a tree
And sitting down before the heat of day.
She took me on her lap and kissed me,
And pointing to the east began to say.
Look on the rising sun! there God does live
And gives his light. and gives his heat away.
And flowers and trees and beasts and men recieve
Comfort in morning. joy in the noon day.
And we are put on earth a little space. .
That we may learn to bear the beams of love.
And these black bodies and this sun.burnt face
Is but a cloud, and like a shady grove.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Black Boy (continued),
Object 9 (Bentley 10, Erdman 10, Keynes 10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The elements of the design combine and develop a selection of those on the previous object. Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd with beard, gown, and crook, sits facing left on a bank. The sun forms a halo behind his head. Two nude boys—the boy on the left dark of skin and his companion pink in this copy—stand in front of him. One, probably the "little English boy" (line 7) whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem, stands at Jesus's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Jesus, who looks down at him. The other boy, probably the little black boy from the previous object stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 12). All three are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads. A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy. Low hills or distant mountains appear on the horizon at left. Although colored brownish-blue in this copy, wavy lines suggest a river running at the foot of the plate. A vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin. Background tinting suggests sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd with long hair, beard, gown, and crook, sits facing left on a bank with two children standing in front of him. He looks down at the child at his knees. The sun forms a halo behind his head. Holding his crook between his legs and across his left shoulder, he rests his left arm on his lap with his hand on his knee. His left foot is exposed.

To the left of the English boy and Christ, a second nude child with short, curly hair, probably the little black boy from the previous object stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 12).

The nude and curly-haired "little English boy" whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem stands at Christ's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Christ, who looks down at him. The boy's right leg is extended backward.
A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy.
A few low hills fill the horizon above the sheep.
The background tinting suggests sunrise or sunset occasioned by the sun forming a halo behind Christ's head.
All three of the figures are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads. Green tinting on the ground beneath the figures suggests grass.
A double vine (the smaller, on the left, very short in this copy) rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin. Both stems bear leaves or flowers.
Jesus sits on a bank in which a tree and double vine are rooted.
A small shadow covers the ground to the left of the two nude boys.
Although colored brownish-blue in this copy, wavy lines may indicate a river running across the foot of the plate.
Low hills or distant mountains appear on the horizon on the left.
In a sitting position, Christ holds a shepherd's crook between his legs and across his left shoulder.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A flowering(?) vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar but detached vegetation completes the circuit around the top and down the left side of the text. The vine in the left margin is intertwined with another vine.

component.illusobjdesc: A flowering(?) vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar but detached vegetation completes the circuit around the top and down the left side of the text. The vine in the left margin is intertwined with another vine.

lg.l: For when our souls have learn'd the heat to bear
The cloud will vanish we shall hear his voice.
Saying: come out from the grove my love & care,
And round my golden tent like lambs rejoice.
Thus did my mother say and kissed me,
And thus I say to little English boy.
When I from black and he from white cloud free,
And round the tent of God like lambs we joy:
Ill shade him from the heat till he can bear,
To lean in joy upon our fathers knee.
And then I'll stand and stroke his silver hair,
And be like him and he will then love me.

desc.objtitle:
The Blossom,
Object 10 (Bentley 11, Erdman 11, Keynes 11)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Originating at lower right, an extravagant plant formed of giant, flame-like leaves surrounds the poem on three sides. In its upper reaches there is a circle of eight figures (clockwise from the far right): (1) a nude, possibly winged infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically; (2) a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, sitting on part of the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title; (3) she seems to be holding an infant in her arms; (4) to the left, a nude winged figure, kneeling or sitting, facing left and probably reading a book or tablet below the figure's left hand; (5 and 6) far left, two winged figures who fly facing one another (one facing away from, and the other facing toward, the viewer); (7 and 8) and a second pair of winged nude figures, kneeling and facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). All the figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central lower pair (2 and 3 above) may be the female blossom who addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. Background washes indicate sky, most likely at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures: at far right is a forward-facing nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically, its left foot forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures: in the center, a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, sits on part of the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title. She may be holding an infant in her arms. The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, this pair may be the female blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures: in the center, a winged female(?) sitting on the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" may be holding an infant in her arms. The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant may represent one of those birds.

The human figures in the plant probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central winged female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant(?) may represent one of those birds.

The human figures in the plant probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central winged female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. Above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title is a nude winged figure, kneeling or sitting, facing left and perhaps reading in the book or tablet to which the figure points with his left arm (raised at about 45 degrees) and hand.
The small winged figure above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title points towards a book or tablet immediately to the left of this figure.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At far left are two nude(?) winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces away from the viewer is perhaps male(?). His arms are raised horizontally, and his legs are spread.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At far left are two nude(?) winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces forward is probably another nude putto, but might be female (her hair may be pulled back in a bun). Her arms are raised at 45 degrees, both to the right, and its legs are together, left forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At top center is a second pair of winged nude figures, kneeling and facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). One leg of the figure on the left is extended backward.
Originating at lower right, an extravagant plant formed of giant, flame-like leaves surrounds the poem on three sides.
A dark shadow covers the ground to the left of the extravagant plant rooted at lower right.
Background washes indicate sky, most likely at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Merry Merry Sparrow
Under leaves so green
A happy Blossom
Sees you swift as arrow
Seek your cradle narrow
Near my Bosom.
Pretty Pretty Robin
Under leaves so green
A happy Blossom
Hears you sobbing sobbing
Pretty Pretty Robin
Near my Bosom.

desc.objtitle:
The Chimney Sweeper,
Object 11 (Bentley 12, Erdman 12, Keynes 12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The illustration seems to depict chimney sweeper Tom Dacre's dream of liberation for himself and his fellow sweeps by an angel, who releases them from their "coffins of black" to run "naked" down a "green plain" and "wash in a river" (lines 14-18). Against a leafy background of plants or perhaps trees are twelve(?) small figures. At bottom right a gowned adult bends forward, reaching toward a nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the coffins of the text. Across the rest of the bottom of the plate are nude figures standing or running with their arms raised in various positions. Two pairs are embracing. Behind the gowned adult a tree grows up the right margin and becomes visually linked to the interlinear decorations. The tinting of the text area suggests a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At bottom right a gowned adult with a halo, presumably the liberating angel of the text, bends forward, reaching toward a nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the coffins of the text.

At bottom right a gowned adult with a halo reaches down toward a nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the "coffins" of the text. This small figure—probably a child—reaches up with the left arm to hold the adult's hand; the right arm is bent and braced against the coffin or earth. One leg, just emerging from underground, is bent at the knee. The child looks up to the adult.
The dark patch under the child emerging (with the adult's help) from the earth may be a grave or one of the "coffins" of the text.

A pair of nude figures stands with their arms raised at 135 degrees; they may be holding hands. They are most likely two of the liberated nude boys of Tom Dacre's dream in the text—"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
Two standing figures embrace. These are presumably two of the naked liberated chimney sweepers of the text.

At bottom left there is a pair of nude figures (the fifth and sixth from the left) who seem to be running with their arms raised. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text-"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).

At bottom left there is a pair of nude figures (the third and fourth from the left) who appear to face each other and embrace, with legs spread apart. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text.

At bottom left there is a pair of nude figures (the first and second from the left) who appear to be running with arms raised vertically or at 135 degrees. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text-"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
A thin, leafy, serpentine tree grows up the right margin, ending to the right of the fifth stanza of the poem.
Green washes below the group of liberated boys suggest the "green [i.e., grassy?] plain" of the text (line 17). Plants (a hedge?) or distant trees form the background.
The tinting of the text area suggest a sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text and margins are busy with vegetative forms (leaves, vines, etc.) and at least five tiny human figures: a chimney sweeper carrying a bag of soot and walking to the right within the "C" of the title, a pair of figures sitting on the tendril above "Sweeper" in the title, and a pair of figures sitting on the vine or tree right of lines 15-16. The capital letters of the title and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and perhaps flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title and descend as a loopy vine in the right margin. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: In the "C" of "Chimney" in the title is a tiny figure that may be a right-facing chimney sweeper carrying a bag of soot.

A pair of tiny figures sit on the tendril above "Sweeper" in the title (and thus may be child chimney sweeps). The one on the left has one arm raised vertically and the other horizontally. He may be holding the vine to the left. The figure on the right, facing left, has at least one arm extended.

A pair of figures (child chimney sweepers?) face each other in the vine, or branches of a tree, right of lines 15-16. The figure on the left stands or leans against the vegetation at his or her back; his or her companion sits. Both have arms raised.

The text and margins are busy with vegetative forms. The capital letters of the title and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and perhaps flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title and descend as a loopy vine in the right margin. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines. The vegetation right of lines 15-16, in which two figures are pictured, may be a tree.

lg.l: When my mother died I was very young.
And my father sold me while yet my tongue,
Could scarcely cry weep weep weep weep.
So your chimneys I sweep & in soot I sleep.
Theres little Tom Dacre. who cried when his head
(That curl'd like a lambs back, was shav'd. so I said.
Hush Tom never mind it, for when your head's bare.
You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair
And so he was quiet, & that very night.
As Tom was a sleeping he had such a sight,
That thousands of sweepers Dick, Joe, Ned & Jack
Were all of them lock'd up in coffins of black,
And by came an Angel who had a bright key,
And he open'd the coffins & set them all free.
(run

Then down a green plain leaping laughing they The illegible word at the end of line 17 may have been intended to be "run". Lacking sufficient space for the word, Blake etched it above line 17 (line 16).
And wash in a river and shine in the Sun.
Then naked & white, all their bags left behind.
They rise upon clouds, and sport in the wind.
And the Angel told Tom if he'd be a good boy,
He'd have God for his father & never want joy.
And so Tom awoke and we rose in the dark
And got with our bags & our brushes to work.
Tho' the morning was cold, Tom was happy & warm,
So if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy Lost,
Object 12 (Bentley 13, Erdman 13, Keynes 13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy in a gown and a hat holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. He is presumably the Little Boy lost, who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 10: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 3, 5). A tree rises on the right and branches over the child's head.

component.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy in a gown holds his arms out toward a triangle of light on the left. Both feet are visible below the hem of his gown, and he steps forward with his right foot. He is presumably the Little Boy lost.
A leafless tree grows on the right. One branch extends toward the top right corner of the design; others extend above the child.
The boy wanders at night in the darkness.

A small boy holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. The triangle is circled by white radiance and dimmer beams of light extend outward. He is presumably the Little Boy lost, who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 10: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 3, 5).
Green coloring on the ground beneath the boy suggests grass. A rectangular shape extending along the ground right of the boy's left foot may be a shadow, but its shape also hints at a grave.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, four winged. The letters of the title sprout vegetative extensions, and there are other bits of vegetation amidst the angels (notably at the bottom), between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There are also two or three seated figures in the title letters, one facing left on the "L" of "Little," one with raised arm in the "B" of "Boy," and possibly one leaning against the left side of the "B" of "Boy." There are four flying birds (though three are barely visible in this copy) and a swan or duck among the lines of the title and the first stanza. Blue background washes suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, all probably female. They are symmetrically arranged, two beside each stanza and two, aligned foot to foot, beneath. They all seem to be gowned, and the four in the right and left margins have wings. The two in the right margin have their arms at their sides; the two wingless figures below float or fly horizontally with one arm raised (with banners or flags of drapery arranged symmetrically); the lower figure in the left margin has its arms by its side; the upper figure on that side faces right, has its left arm raised vertically, and may be pointing to the scene above or holding a triangular object.

There are two or three figures sitting in the title letters, one facing left, with bent arm raised to its head, on the "L" of "Little," one sitting with arm raised at about 135 degrees in the "B" of "Boy," and possibly one leaning against the left side of the "B" of "Boy."

Four birds fly among the lines of the title and the first stanza: over "lost" in the title, over "where" and "going" in line 2, and after "fast" in line 4, though the last three are barely visible in this copy. There is a swan or duck above the "y" of "Boy."

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above most of the title. The "y" of "Boy" is extended, and an unattached clump of plant-like decoration surrounds the right end of the title. There are other bits of leafy (and/or flowery) vegetation around the two figures at the bottom, between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There is a particularly loopy, leafy tendril after line 6 and between the two stanzas.
Blue washes behind the text area suggest sky.

lg.l: Father, father, where are you going
O do not walk so fast,
Speak father, speak to your little boy
Or else I shall be lost
The night was dark no father was there
The child was wet with dew,
The mire was deep, & the child did weep
And away the vapour flew

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy Found,
Object 13 (Bentley 14, Erdman 14, Keynes 14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a dim (not quite dark) landscape dominated by the trunks of three large trees, a long-haired adult figure, visually ambiguous but male according to the text, dressed in a high-waisted long gown holds the hand of a gowned child. The two figures look at one another as they walk forward, on grassy ground, toward the viewer. A halo appears above the adult's head; the brim of the boy's hat also suggests a halo. The child raises his right arm. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 3-7).

component.illusobjdesc: A long-haired, haloed adult figure in a high-waisted long gown—visually ambiguous though the reference to "God . . . like his father" (lines 5-6) suggests that he is male—walks beside a boy whose hand he holds (he holds his opposite arm by his side). If this is God, it is very probably Christ, given the similarities between this figure and several of Blake's other representations of Christ. Both feet are exposed; his left foot is forward. He looks down toward the boy.

The two figures walk forward toward the viewer. A gowned male child with short hair walks forward toward the viewer beside a similarly dressed adult whose hand he holds and up at whom he looks. The little boy steps forward with his right leg. The child raises his left arm at 45 degrees, his right at 135 degrees. The brim of the boy's hat hints at a halo. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 3-7).

A dim (not quite dark) landscape—the "lonely dale" (line 9) of the text—is dominated by three large and ominous tree trunks—two left and one right—without visible leaves or other vegetation. The trunks arch to create a kind of dark tunnel in which the two figures walk. Green coloring on the ground below the figures suggests grass; there may be additional indistinguishable vegetation behind the figures.
Dark but small shadows fall on the ground to the right of the two figures' feet.
The darkness suggests that the time is still the "night" (Object 12, line 8) specified in "The Little Boy lost." The patches of yellow wash in the background sky may indicate impending sunrise.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit with long hair flies with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her. The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title and into the left margin; another group of detached vegetative decorations fills the space below the poem and up the right margin to the angelic spirit. Another loopy vine descends in the left margin. Pink washes behind the text suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit, probably female, floats with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. She looks sharply upward, as if at the design above. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her, and these may cast the shadow behind her against the right margin. This may be the child's "mother" (line 8) to whom he is led.
A gowned angelic spirit, probably female, floats with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. She and her gown may cast a shadow behind her against the right margin of the plate.
Pink washes behind the text suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title. The capital letters of the title all have such extensions. The "y" of "Boy" extends far to the left and down the left margin, and the vertical stroke of the "d" of "Found" is extravagantly extended to fill the space above the angel. Another cluster of vine-like decorations begins in the right margin in front of the legs of the angel and extends downward (with at least one leaf) into the space below the poem.

lg.l: The little boy lost in the lonely fen,
Led by the wand'ring light,
Began to cry, but God ever nigh,
Appeard like his father in white.
He kissed the child & by the hand led
And to his mother brought,
Who in sorrow pale, thro' the lonely dale
Her little boy weeping sought.

desc.objtitle:
Laughing Song,
Object 14 (Bentley 15, Erdman 15, Keynes 15)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Eight figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation. Five figures sit behind the table, away from the viewer; the female at far right extends her arm to hold a drinking glass that rests on the table. Near the ends of the table on the front side, two other figures sit in chairs that are turned sideways, facing one another. Each figure holds a glass on the table. Between them an eighth figure, a male in tights, stands facing away from the viewer. In upraised hands he holds a glass (right) and a plumed hat (left). The faces of all but one of the figures on the far side of the table are visible. The three figures on the near side face away from the viewer toward the rest of the company. The text mentions "green woods," "meadows," and a "table" in "the shade" (lines 3, 7, 11-12). The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the shadows on the ground, lower right. Washes above the background vegetation suggest sky at sunrise or, more probably, sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At the center is a curly-haired male in knee-length tights standing poised and erect facing away from the viewer. His legs are spread apart; his right leg is straight, his left is extended left, the foot held with its toes pointed. His arms are bent and raised vertically. In his right hand is a wine glass or cup, in his left a hat with a plume. In the context of the poem his actions suggest that he may be singing.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far left is a female with hair pulled back in a bun and wearing a long gown. Her left leg is extended slightly forward; her right leg is drawn back under her. Her right arm is extended to hold a glass that rests on the table. Her left arm rests on the back of her chair, and her body is twisted counterclockwise as if to face the female across the table from her.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far right is a short-haired male in knee-length tights. His left leg is extended forward and his foot is visible; his right leg is drawn back under him. His right arm is extended along the table surface to hold a glass; only the upper part of his left is visible near the back of the chair. His lower body faces left, with his torso facing forward and his head twisted clockwise to face the two females across the table.

Five figures are seated behind the table. The figure at far left seems to be a female in a hat with a round brim. She faces forward and perhaps looks at the female seated at the left end of the table.
Five figures are seated behind a table. We see the upper body and hair of a figure, second from the left. This figure seems to have her or his upper body twisted away from the viewer.

Five figures are seated behind the table. Third from the left is a female with curly(?) hair and wearing a gown. Her head is turned right and tilted up slightly. Her right arm is raised to 45 degrees, her left bent at the elbow.

Five figures are seated behind the table. Second from the right is a female in a high-waisted gown. Her hair is either short or pulled back. She faces forward, and her right arm, which is bent at the elbow, may rest on the table.

Five figures are seated behind the table. At far right is a female wearing a hat with a round brim. At the end of an outstretched right arm she may hold a glass that rests on the table, which is clearer in other copies.

Several figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation, probably trees. Though the vegetation is not clearly defined, the text mentions "meadows" and "green woods."
The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the dark shadows on the ground lower right and extending along the lower margin of the design.

In front of the table, near each end, two figures sit in symmetrically-placed chairs turned parallel with the table. The chairs have backs and rear legs integrated into a single convex curve. The front legs of the chair on the right curve forward to balance the curve of the rear legs.
Four figures hold drinking glasses. Three rest on the table; the fourth is in the right hand of the central standing figure.
There is a plumed hat with a round brim in the left hand of the central standing figure. The women at far left and far right sitting behind the table also have on round-brimmed hats.
Washes above the background vegetation suggest sky at sunrise or, more probably, sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the decoration is marginal rather than strictly interlinear. Numerous birds, especially in the bottom margin, ornament areas around the text. There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing," and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines and across the bottom. Washes behind the text suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Several birds of various sizes perch and fly on and among the vegetation. Around the title, to the left a bird with outspread wings ascends vertically; another glides over "Song"; and at the right a third dives. In the right margin, after "shade" (line 11), a tiny bird ascends steeply. The small winged creature farther to the right may be another bird or insect. Across the bottom of the plate are seven other birds (left to right): two flying above the vine, with outspread wings and the second with a forked tail, the right one ascending; below the vine a third, descending; a fourth, with forked tail, perching on the vine; to its right, above the vine a fifth bird flying, and below the vine, a sixth ascending and, finally, a seventh perching with wings raised.

There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing," though the tendril from the "h" is slightly detached in copy S. Both have loops, and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines and across the bottom.
Light brown washes along the bottom edge of the plate, particularly in the lower left corner, may indicate a ground line or shadows. Washes behind the text suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: When the green woods laugh. with the voice of joy
And the dimpling stream runs laughing by,
When the air does laugh with our merry wit,
And the green hill laughs with the noise of it.
When the meadows laugh with lively green
And the grasshopper laughs in the merry scene,
When Mary and Susan and Emily,
With their sweet round mouths sing Ha, Ha, He,
When the painted birds laugh in the shade
Where our table with cherries and nuts is spread
Come live & be merry and join with me,
To sing the sweet chorus of Ha, Ha, He,

desc.objtitle:
A CRADLE SONG,
Object 15 (Bentley 16, Erdman 16, Keynes 16)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Indeterminate (but varied) vegetation interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. There are three figures in the letters "A," "C," and "D" of the title; five(?) in the left margin; and four(?) in the right. Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: There are three figures in the letters of the title: a piper playing(?) as he leans against the left side of the "A"; a figure sitting inside the "C," perhaps facing right; and a figure standing inside the "D."
A piper plays his pipe(?) as he leans against the letter "A" in the title.

There are five(?) figures in the left margin (top to bottom): a gowned woman standing with her arm raised vertically beside the second stanza; a small winged(?) figure next to "Hover" (line 12), and just beneath it a sitting figure, who is almost completely obscured in this copy; a seated, gowned, hunched over figure, with head lowered and at least one arm on its lap, facing right, left of the fifth stanza; and, barely visible beside the sixth stanza, possibly a standing figure.

There are four(?) figures visible in the right margin (top to bottom): a gowned figure seated facing right, with head down, right of line 5; a gowned female(?) figure lying horizontally, arm extended, in the flame-like vegetation to the right of lines 6 and 7; a figure barely visible seated on a vine right of lines 16-17 with one arm braced against the vine, the other arm possibly extended with the hand on the knee; and a figure walking right at the end of lines 17-18.

Indeterminate vegetation of various sorts interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. The dominant form is perhaps the vegetation with flame-like leaves that swirls in the spaces of the right margin (with a more conventional leaf or two at bottom right), underneath the title, and down the left margin. Tendrils extending from both margins help separate the stanzas from one another. The vine right of the final stanza on the plate has several loops suggesting a spiral. The vine full of leaves and flowers(?) that extends across the top of the plate above the title and fills the top right corner and the space right of the first stanza is distinct from the flame-like vegetation that dominates the rest of the plate. Extensions of letters in the title contribute to both forms of vegetation: the initial "A" and "C" to the vine above, the "S" to both. In the text of the poem, occasional letters have modest decorative extensions, and there are a few bits of stray decorative vegetation.
Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset, possibly with a dark shadow in the lower left corner.

lg.l: Sweet dreams form a shade,
O'er my lovely infants head,
Sweet dreams of pleasant streams,
By happy silent moony beams
Sweet sleep with soft down.
Weave thy brows an infant crown.
Sweet sleep Angel mild,
Hover o'er my happy child.
Sweet smiles in the night,
Hover over my delight.
Sweet smiles Mothers smiles
All the livelong night beguiles.
Sweet moans, dovelike sighs,
Chase not slumber from thy eyes,
Sweet moans.sweeter smiles,
All the dovelike moans beguiles.
Sleep sleep happy child.
All creation slept and smil'd.
Sleep sleep. happy sleep.
While o'er thee thy mother weep
Sweet babe in thy face.
Holy image I can trace.
Sweet babe once like thee.
Thy maker lay and wept for me

l.note: The last three letters of "Wept" printed very lightly in copy S.

desc.objtitle:
A CRADLE SONG (continued),
Object 16 (Bentley 17, Erdman 17, Keynes 17)

illustration.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother dressed in a high-waisted gown and hat or headdress of some sort leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a hooded wicker cradle. The infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 8). A carpet with many colors covers the floor. Fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background, and creases in the material create shadows on the left.

component.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother, dressed in a high-waisted gown and hat, scarf, or headdress of some sort, leans over an infant in a cradle. She faces right; at least her right arm, and probably her left, are folded in front of her.

A nurse or mother leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a cradle. The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the smiling infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 8).
The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo.
An infant sleeps in a wicker cradle with a hood that arches over the infant's head.
A carpet with many colors covers the floor.
Fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background. Creases in the material create shadows on the left.
The mother or nurse sits in a curved-back chair.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 6) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the left margin and beneath the text. In the left margin there are four human figures: beside the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands with an infant(?) in her arms; left of lines 6-7 is a running or leaping figure with arms raised horizontally; and left of line 8 is a small gowned figure facing, and perhaps walking, left. Washes behind the text indicate sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 6) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the right margin and beneath the text. Two of these are extensions of letters in the text: the "S" of "Smiles" (line 6) and the "p" of "peace" (line 9).
Left of the first stanza, a woman(?) stands or walks, facing right, with an infant(?) in her arms.
Left of lines 6-7, a small figure strides or leaps or hovers in the air, facing right. Its legs are spread apart and its arms raised horizontally.
A tiny figure, perhaps gowned, hovers or walks to the left just left of line 8. This may be the "infant" referenced in the first word of line 8.
Washes behind the text indicate sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Wept for me for thee for all.
When he was an infant small.
Thou his image ever see,
Heavenly face that smiles on thee.
Smiles on thee on me on all.
Who became an infant small,
Infant smiles are his own smiles,
Heaven & earth to peace beguiles

desc.objtitle:
The Divine Image,
Object 17 (Bentley 18, Erdman 18, Keynes 18)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at right in the strip of grassy ground that runs across the bottom of the plate, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward flourish at top left. The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a vine with many flowers or blossoms that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin right of the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant, which the vine continues to climb, finally terminating just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure. There are several human figures on and around the plants: (at top left) a gowned female with long hair walks right; a second gowned female with long hair floats behind her, pointing right; two figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer; (at bottom right) a gowned, Christ-like figure, his head surrounded by a large halo, stands with left arm extended, perhaps touching the left hand of a nude(?) male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically; below and in front of this pair, a third figure, perhaps a nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm. Background washes indicate sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At top left, a gowned woman with long hair walks right; in her left hand, she holds a vase or pitcher by her side. Another gowned female with long hair hovers behind her, pointing right with her right hand.
The gowned woman walking at top left may carry a vase or pitcher in her left hand.
Two gowned figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer.

At bottom right stands a Christ-like figure, his head surrounded by a large halo. He wears a high-waisted gown and extends his left arm, perhaps to touch the left hand of a male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically toward the hand of the standing figure. The pink and blue tinting of his body in this copy may represent nudity. Below and in front of the male pair, a third figure, perhaps a nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm. The male and female conceivably represent Adam and Eve.

A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at bottom right, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward curl at top left.

The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a vine with many flowers or blossoms that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin behind the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant (sending out occasional tendrils to the left, into the spaces left by short lines of the poem) until it terminates in a cluster of blossoms that dangles just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure.
The flame-like plant and vine are apparently rooted at bottom right in the strip of grassy ground that runs across the bottom of the plate.
Background washes indicate sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: To Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
All pray in their distress:
And to these virtues of delight
Return their thankfulness.
For Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
Is God our father dear;
And Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
Is Man his child and care.
For Mercy has a human heart
Pity, a human face:
And Love, the human form divine,
And Peace. the human dress.
Then every man of every clime,
That prays in his distress,
Prays to the human form divine
Love Mercy Pity Peace.
And all must love the human form,
In heathen, turk or jew,
Where Mercy, Love & Pity dwell,
There God is dwelling too.

desc.objtitle:
HOLY THURSDAY,
Object 18 (Bentley 19, Erdman 19, Keynes 19)
