illustration.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some may hold one another around the waist or shoulder. Several of the boys wear hats or caps. They are led by a pair of gowned adults, both with hats and each carrying a staff or scepter. At the bottom of the plate a similar procession occurs, though with seven pairs of girls instead of nine of boys, walking left instead of right on grassy ground, and led by a single gowned female(?) figure who holds an open book. The girls wear dresses, and some may also wear hats. The figures altogether represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 3-7). Washes behind the text suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some hold one another around the waist or shoulder. Several of the boys wear hats or caps. Along with the figures at the bottom, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" (lines 4-6).

The procession of children is led by a pair of robed adults, probably male(?), both with hats, and each holding a staff or scepter. They are the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" (line 6).
The beadles at the head of the procession hold a staff or scepter, two of the "wands" (line 6) of the text.

Seven pairs of girls walk left on grassy ground, led by a single adult figure. The girls wear dresses, and some may also wear hats. Their positions are not always clear; girls in the fourth and fifth pairs from the right gesture with their hands. Along with the figures at the top, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 3-7).
The procession of girls is led by a single gowned figure, of indeterminate gender, who holds an open book. The figure appears to be wearing a wig or cap.
The robed figure who is leading the procession holds an open book and may be wearing a cap or wig.
Shadows fall on the ground to the right of the second, third, and fourth pairs of girls from the right.
The green wash on the ground under the feet of the procession of girls suggests grass.
Washes behind the text suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures. The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY") and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird (below "into the" in line 6) or human figure (beneath "innocent" in line 11), both clearer in other copies. Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves but including a bird perching on a central vine, wings outspread, facing the viewer.

component.illusobjdesc: Though clearer in other copies there is a tiny human figure, sitting on a vine with arms raised horizontally, beneath "innocent" in line 11.

Though clearer in other copies, there are birds beneath "into the" in line 6—flying to the right—and beneath "you drive" in line 15—perching and facing forward, with wings outspread, on a vine. The latter bird may be an eagle.

The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures. The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY") and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird or human figure. Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves.

lg.l: Twas on a Holy Thursday their innocent faces clean
The children walking two & two in red & blue & green
(snow
Grey headed beadles walkd before with wands as white as
Till into the high dome of Pauls they like Thames waters flow.
O what a multitude they seemd these flowers of London town
Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own
The hum of multitudes was there but multitudes of lambs
Thousands of little boys & girls raising their innocent hands
Now like a mighty wind they raise to heaven the voice of song
Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heaven among
Beneath them sit the aged men wise guardians of the poor
Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door

desc.objtitle:
Night,
Object 19 (Bentley 20, Erdman 20, Keynes 20)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second tree, much smaller, is also rooted lower right; its branches cross behind the larger tree above the angel opposite "nest" in line 19. A second branch of the larger tree continues up the right side of the plate to complete the circle around the title. Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps a little beyond the point where the tree bends left, is unclear. Just left of the trees, lower right, a lion lies in a cave with vegetation arching over it. There are winged angelic figures in the tree, one sitting with wings folded on a branch and a second hovering just above the lion's den. Two birds perch on a branch right of line 6. In the left margin are other figures and objects (bottom to top): one gowned, standing on the shadowed ground and facing the third stanza; just above that, another figure, gowned and facing forward and possibly winged; another, arms raised vertically, standing on a sphere (the sun or moon?); just above that another, smaller, with wings and arms outspread. All the figures may be the angels described in the text (Object 19, stanzas 2-3; Object 20, stanza 1). Above the top figure on the left, left of line 6, is another sphere (the sun or moon?); scattered across this same space in the left margin are ten dots, perhaps stars. Dark blue and gray background washes suggest a night sky.

component.illusobjdesc: There are winged, gowned angelic figures in the tree, one facing right, sitting with wings folded on a branch and a second with arms raised horizontally, hovering or standing on one foot just above the lion's den.

In the left margin are other figures (bottom to top): one gowned, standing and facing right toward the third stanza; just above, a winged figure who may be gowned and face forward; another standing, arms raised vertically, on a sphere (the sun or moon?); just above that another, with wings and arms outspread.

Rooted at bottom right, a slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second tree, much smaller, is also rooted lower right; its branches cross in front of and behind the larger tree above the angel opposite "nest" in line 19. A second branch of the larger tree continues up the right side of the plate to complete the circle around the title. Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps a little beyond the point where the tree bends left, is unclear. Some indeterminate vegetation extends in an arch over the cave, lower right.
A strip of grass runs across the bottom of the plate; at right it covers a hill or bank.
In the grass-covered(?) hill or bank at right is a cave. Alternatively, this formation may be composed of arching vegetation.
Two birds perch on a branch right of line 6.
A lion lies facing forward in a cave and may be sleeping.

In the left margin are two small circles, probably representing spheres, one above the figures and the other beneath the feet of the second figure from the top. One may be the moon and the other the sun. Between the two spheres are ten scattered dots that may represent stars.
Dark blue and gray background washes suggest a night sky.

lg.l: Night

component.illusobjdesc: The style of lettering in the title integrates it into the tree.

lg.l: The sun descending in the west.
The evening star does shine.
The birds are silent in their nest.
And I must seek for mine,
The moon like a flower.
In heavens high bower;
With silent delight,
Sits and smiles on the night.
Farewell green fields and happy groves,
Where flocks have took delight;
Where lambs have nibbled, silent moves
The feet of angels bright;
Unseen they pour blessing,
And joy without ceasing,
On each bud and blossom.,
And each sleeping bosom.
They look in every thoughtless nest.
Where birds are coverd warm;
They visit caves of every beast,
To keep them all from harm:
If they see any weeping,
That should have been sleeping
They pour sleep on their head
And sit down by their bed.

desc.objtitle:
Night (continued),
Object 20 (Bentley 21, Erdman 21, Keynes 21)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A large tree, with a leafy vine lower left, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. On the ground, in front of a backdrop of plants, five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. To the left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females, perhaps walking. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right. The one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward and perhaps down; the one to the right looks left. The upper bodies of the figures in both groups are lit from behind, perhaps to suggest haloes and thus the angels mentioned in the text (Object 19, line 15; Object 20, line 8). The light behind the two figures on the right may be the moon with dark beams of light emanating from it. In the vine-encircled tree trunk in the left margin are two other gowned female figures, perhaps the angels mentioned in the text. The lowest stands on a limb of the tree and has one arm raised vertically; the top-most may face forward (the position of her head is unclear in this copy). A dark shadow covers the lower edge of the grassy ground and the tree trunk, lower left. Dark blue and gray background washes suggest a night sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. To their left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females, perhaps walking. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right. The one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward and perhaps down; the one to the right looks left. The upper bodies of the figures in both groups are lit from behind, perhaps to suggest haloes and thus the angels mentioned in the text (Object 19, line 15; Object 20, line 8). The light behind the two figures on the right may be the moon.

The upper bodies of the figures in both groups are lit from behind, perhaps to suggest haloes and thus the angels mentioned in the text (Object 19, line 15; Object 20, line 8). The light behind the two figures on the right may be the moon with dark beams of light emanating from it.

In the tree trunk in the left margin are two gowned female figures, perhaps the angels mentioned in the text. The lowest figure stands on a limb and raises one arm vertically. The figure above, left of the first stanza on this plate, may be facing forward (her head position is unclear in this copy).

A large tree, with a leafy vine lower left, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. Five figures stand on the grass against a backdrop of plants or other vegetation. Several vines grow behind and to the right of the base of the tree at left.
Shadows fall to the right of both groups of standing figures and darken the base of the tree at left.
Dark blue and gray background washes suggest a night sky.

lg.l: When wolves and tygers howl for prey
They pitying stand and weep;
Seeking to drive their thirst away,
And keep them from the sheep.
But if they rush dreadful;
The angels most heedful,
Recieve each mild spirit.
New worlds to inherit.
And there the lions ruddy eyes,
Shall flow with tears of gold:
And pitying the tender cries,
And walking round the fold:
Saying; wrath by his meekness
And by his health. sickness,
Is driven away.
From our immortal day.
And now beside thee bleating lamb.
I can lie down and sleep;
Or think on him who bore thy name.
Grase after thee and weep.
For wash'd in lifes river.
My bright mane for ever.
Shall shine like the gold.
As I guard o'er the fold.

desc.objtitle:
The School Boy,
Object 21 (Bentley 53, Erdman 53, Keynes 53)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text are three boys playing a game (of marbles?) on the ground. To the right of the boys is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. On the vines are four other children: (bottom to top) one—long-haired and thus perhaps a girl—standing with arms raised, two boys(?) climbing, and another boy(?) sitting and reading. In the left margin is another elaborate vine with a large bird perched near its top, left of the first stanza. A figure stands in these vines, perhaps facing right, just left of the fourth stanza. Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The short-haired boy in tights on the left kneels on the ground with his arm down, as if poised to shoot a marble in the game that he and the other children present are playing.
The short-haired boy in tights in the middle kneels, leaning forward, with his arms braced to support his weight. He looks down toward the hand of the boy to the left.

The right-most child—probably male—in the group below the text has short hair and wears tights. He is sitting, bending sharply forward with head and arms down. Though facing left, he appears to be looking down at the ground rather than at the game.

A long-haired nude girl or boy stands at the intersection of two vines, perhaps in the process of climbing them (like the figure just above it). The left-facing figure's head is thrown sharply back, its arms are raised vertically to hold onto the vines above its head, and its weight is on its extended left leg.

A short-haired boy in tights climbs in the intertwining vines that extend up the right margin. Facing forward and looking down and slightly right, he raises his arms vertically to hold onto the vines over his head. His right leg is drawn up toward his body; his left leg is extended along the vine.

A child in knee-length tights or breeches and a shirt, probably a boy though other identifying features are not shown, climbs the vine. His arms are raised vertically to cling to the vines over his head. His legs are spread wide.
Facing right, a child of indeterminate sex in tights(?) sits in a curve at the top of a vine in the right margin. He holds, and appears to be reading, a book.
Barely visible, a figure stands, probably gowned and facing right, in the tree left of the fourth stanza. The figure's right arm may be bent at the elbow.
A bird with long forked tail and wings partially spread perches in the vegetation to the left of the first stanza.

Behind the right-most figure below the text is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation—perhaps grass—and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. These appear to grow out of a small grassy mound. The vines have numerous tendrils and leaves and at least one large cluster of fruit, to the right of line 21.
Two large intertwining grapevines extend up the right margin to the top of the plate and appear to grow out of a small grassy mound. Dark shadows cover the ground below and to the right of the mound.
Rooted at lower left, a slender tree with leaves extends up the left margin and ends opposite line 8(?). An intertwined vine climbs the tree, with one loop left of the fifth stanza.
Three children play a game, perhaps marbles. Four(?) marbles are just barely visible on the ground beneath the right-most child.
Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal trees and vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration). Tendrils from the vines in the right margin—part of the main illustration—are extended into some of the spaces left by short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration).

lg.l: I love to rise in a summer morn,
When the birds sing on every tree;
The distant huntsman winds his horn,
And the sky-lark sings with me.
O! what sweet company.
But to go to school in a summer morn,
O! it drives all joy away;
Under a cruel eye outworn.
The little ones spend the day,
In sighing and dismay.
Ah! then at times I drooping sit,
And spend many an anxious hour,
Nor in my book can I take delight,
Nor sit in learnings bower.
Worn thro' with the dreary shower.
How can the bird that is born for joy,
Sit in a cage and sing.
How can a child when fears annoy.
But droop his tender wing.
And forget his youthful spring.
O! father & mother, if buds are nip'd,
And blossoms blown away,
And if the tender plants are strip'd
Of their joy in the springing day,
By sorrow and cares dismay.
How shall the summer arise in joy,
Or the summer fruits appear. (troy
Or how shall we gather what griefs des
Or bless the mellowing year.
When the blasts of winter appear.

desc.objtitle:
Spring,
Object 22 (Bentley 22, Erdman 22, Keynes 22)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Sitting beneath the branches of a tree with its trunk behind her, a gowned woman with hair pulled back looks out toward a flock of grazing sheep. She holds a nude infant—perhaps her own—who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward the sheep. Low hills define the horizon above the sheep. The rose coloring of the sky above the hills indicates a sunrise or sunset. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem.

component.illusobjdesc: Sitting to the right of a large tree trunk, a gowned woman with hair pulled back into a bun looks out toward a flock of grazing sheep. She holds a nude infant—perhaps her own—who stands in her lap. Her right foot is visible beneath the hem of her gown.

A seated woman holds her(?) short-haired nude infant, who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward the sheep. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem.

A mother and her(?) infant overlook a flock of grazing sheep. In the final stanza of the poem, an infant or child speaks to a "Little Lamb," and this may be the animal with head raised to the right of the woman's left knee.
The horizon above the sheep is defined by low hills. Above, the rose coloring of the sky indicates a sunrise or sunset.
The leaves of a tree, its trunk just right of the left margin, extend over the woman and infant.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. A vine curls left of the "S" of "Spring" and dangles (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring"; curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, a loopy tendril, and several tassels of grain. Another vine curves around the end of long line 11 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate, ending in two tassels of grain. Two winged angels occupy this vegetation, one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe right of lines 3-4; the other reclining on one arm right of line 12. Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset, as in the scene above.

component.illusobjdesc: Two winged angels with obscure features occupy the vegetation to the right of the text: one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe opposite lines 3-4; the other, wings outspread, facing forward yet looking right, reclining on one arm opposite line 12.

Most of the decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. A vine curls left of the "S" of "Spring" and dangles (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring"; curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, a loopy tendril, and several tassels of grain. Another vine curves around the end of long line 11 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate. This vine ends in two tassels of grain.
Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset, as in the scene above.

lg.l: Sound the Flute!
Now it's mute.
Birds delight
Day and Night.
Nightingale
In the dale
Lark in Sky
Merrily (Year
Merrily Merrily to welcome in the
Little Boy
Full of joy.

desc.objtitle:
Spring (continued),
Object 23 (Bentley 23, Erdman 23, Keynes 23)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with curly hair reclines on grassy ground with water (a lake or river?) below. With both hands the infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Two sheep also lie on the ground, left and right of the infant. He may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem. Above, the coloring of the text area suggests sky at sunrise or sunset, as on the previous object.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with short, curly hair reclines, with his left leg crossed over his extended right leg, in the midst of a group of three sheep. With his left hand he touches the neck—and with his right the back—of a lamb to the left; the two of them look at one another. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem.

An infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Grown sheep lie on the right and left; the one on the right faces forward while the one on the left appears to be watching the lamb and infant.
The green wash on the ground beneath the infant and sheep suggests grass.
Water, probably a lake or river, appears just above the bottom margin of the design.
The background coloring suggests sky at sunrise or sunset, as on the previous object.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two grain tassels grow from this framing vine; the lower tassel dangles through the right side of the vignette. Two clusters of similar vegetation, each with at least one grain tassel, fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There is a figure associated with each cluster of vegetation in the right margin: below, a gowned angel with large wings sitting on a curve of the plant with her(?) knees drawn up and her head down; above, a gowned figure standing, with arms outspread, in a semi-circle made by the plant.

component.illusobjdesc: Right of the first stanza, a gowned figure stands in a semi-circle made by a vine or leaf. Her(?) arms are outspread, partially hidden by the vine-like plant that circles around in front of her, and she may point upward. She faces left with her right foot extended behind her and her upper body possibly twisted forward.
Right of the last stanza, a winged, gowned angel sits on a curve of the plant with her(?) legs drawn up and her head down, her body facing left.

Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two clusters of similar vegetation fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There are grain tassels at the right side of the lower vignette, to the right of lines 14-16, below the last few words in line 8, and just below the top right corner of the plate.

lg.l: Little Girl
Sweet and small,
Cock does crow
So do you,
Merry voice
Infant noise
Merrily Merrily to welcome in the Year
Little Lamb
Here I am,
Come and lick
My white neck.
Let me pull
Your soft Wool.
Let me kiss
Your soft face, Year
Merrily Merrily we welcome in the

desc.objtitle:
NURSES Song Nurse's Song,
Object 24 (Bentley 24, Erdman 24, Keynes 24)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the bottom, under the (lower?) limb of a tree with a few leaves, seven children—four boys and two, probably three, girls—hold hands and play, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. The two children furthest left stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth, between them. A matron-figure in hat and gown, evidently the nurse of the title, sits on the ground against the trunk and reads a book in her lap. To the right is a second, slimmer tree with a vine around its trunk. There are two "hills" (line 14) in the background with a notch between them. The coloring of the sky behind the text indicates a sunset (line 7).

component.illusobjdesc: Seven children hold hands and play vigorously, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. Clockwise from the left: The two children furthest left (a girl[?] and a boy) stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth used in a game, between them; a girl raises her arms horizontally and faces right with legs outspread; a boy raises his arms higher, as does the long-haired(?) girl to the right of him, whose leg is extended behind her; holding her hand, a boy runs left and reaches forward to hold the hand of another running or striding boy, left leg extended behind him, who raises his free left hand as he moves left and back, perhaps toward the opening between the pair furthest left. All the girls wear gowns; all the boys wear knee breeches or tights. These are the "little ones" who "leaped & shouted & laugh'd" (line 17) and remonstrate with the nurse in the poem.

Facing right, a matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title who remonstrates with the children of the poem, sits on the ground or a low seat against the trunk of a tree and reads a book that she holds in her lap.

On the left is the trunk of a tree whose lowermost branch, with a few leaves, spreads over the nurse who sits at the base of its trunk. On the right is a second, slimmer tree, with more leafy branches and a vine climbs its trunk. Between the trees is the grassy "green" of line 3.
Shadows presumably cast by the branches of the tree at left darken the grass at the bottom edge of the design.
There are two "hills" (line 14) in the background with a notch between them. The coloring of the sky behind the above text suggests the sunset alluded to in line 7.
The nurse reads a book that she holds in her lap.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On this plate the interlinear designs are especially dense around the title, in the margins, and between the three stanzas. The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g." There are also three prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 6. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 6, 10, and 14) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin. Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," climbing the left stroke and sitting on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one reaching downward through the following "u," joining hands with another who reaches up from below; one leaning against the "S" of "Song" who may hold a pen or quill in his(?) right hand and write on a piece of paper in his lap; one standing(?) at the top of the "S" of "Song", facing right and reaching overhead to grasp the curling vine above; two beneath "Song" on the long horizontal descender of the "g"; one reclining, with right arm raised horizontally, on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 4 and another(?), who merges almost indistinguishably with the vegetation, in a contracted posture on the leafy structure at the end of line 6. Between the lines there are a few birdlike shapes.

component.illusobjdesc: Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation. Clockwise from top left: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," one (nude?) climbing the left stroke and the other sitting, facing right, on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one hovering in the following "u," reaching downward and joining hands with another who reaches up from below, where he/she (colored like the vegetation in this copy) is seated, facing left, on the end of the long horizontal descender of the "g"; one facing left and leaning, with one leg drawn up, against the "S" of "Song" who may hold a pen or quill in his(?) right hand and write on a piece of paper in his lap; two reclining beneath "Song" on the long horizontal descender of the "g," the one on the left straddling the vegetation; one, arm raised, reclining on the bit of vegetation and facing left at the end of line 4 and another(?), who merges almost indistinguishably with the vegetation, seated in a contracted posture, on the leafy structure at the end of line 6.
Facing left with one leg drawn up, the figure leaning against the "S" of "Song" may hold a pen or quill in his(?) right hand and write on a piece of paper in his lap.
Though clearer in other copies, there are two or three birdlike shapes above "for it is" in line 11 and another above "hills" in the last line.

The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g." There are several long, slender leaves (the descender on the "g," for instance), and there are three other prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 6. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 6, 10, and 14) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin.
A few lines may represent water into which the branches of the willow descend.

lg.l: When the voices of children are heard on the green
And laughing is heard on the hill,
My heart is at rest within my breast
And every thing else is still
Then come home my children, the sun is gone down
And the dews of night arise
Come come leave off play, and let us away
Till the morning appears in the skies
No no let us play, for it is yet day
And we cannot go to sleep
Besides in the sky, the little birds fly
And the hills are all coverd with sheep
Well well go & play till the light fades away
And then go home to bed
The little ones leaped & shouted & laugh'd
And all the hills ecchoed

desc.objtitle:
Infant Joy,
Object 25 (Bentley 25, Erdman 25, Keynes 25)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate in a strip of grassy ground, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding an infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. Each of her small wings is marked with a dot. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 7). A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the center-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one. Pink and yellow washes across the lower half of the design suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding a nude infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 7).

Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate in a strip of grassy ground, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a drooping closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the middle-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one.
Pink and yellow washes across the lower half of the design suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: I have no name
I am but two days old.__
What shall I call thee?
I happy am
Joy is my name,__
Sweet joy befall thee!
Pretty joy!
Sweet joy but two days old,
Sweet joy I call thee;
Thou dost smile.
I sing the while
Sweet joy befall thee,

desc.objtitle:
The Voice of the Ancient Bard,
Object 26 (Bentley 54, Erdman 54, Keynes 54)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned, bearded old man stands, playing a large harp, before an audience of perhaps two children—standing in the middle of the group—and six older youths. He may be the bard of the title. To the left stand two young females who embrace. To the right stand the two children and a group of three gowned females who face the bard. At their feet, facing them, kneels another female. All the figures appear to be gowned. The scene is set outdoors on a strip of slightly inclined grassy ground with a dark shadow lower right. A palm-like frond arches over the head of the figure at far right and the vine in the left margin of the text dangles down into this major design above the heads of the embracing couple. Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At left stands an embracing couple. The young female faces away from the viewer with her visible right arm raised vertically to embrace the neck of her companion. Her right leg is extended behind her with her foot lifted slightly off the ground.

At left stands an embracing couple. Facing left, the taller figure might be an older female. Her hair is short or drawn back into a bun. She looks down at the other figure and holds her visible hand on her companion's buttocks.

A tall, bearded old man in a gown stands facing right as he plays a large triangular harp with a bent right arm and a raised left one. He may be the bard of the title. His right foot shows beneath the hem of his garment.

In the middle of the group, just right of the old man, stand two gowned children (distinctly shorter than their companions). The listening child to the left faces forward and looks up toward the bard or his harp. The curly-haired child on the right faces right as he looks up toward the threesome to the right.

At right stand three young gowned females, at least the one on the left with short hair. They look toward and listen to the bard. The left-most of the three holds her arm, slightly bent, at her side; the right-most faces left and bends her arm up to hold the arm of the middle figure. At their feet and facing away from the viewer kneels a fourth young female similarly dressed and coiffured. She looks toward the threesome rather than at the bard. Her left arm is bent upward, with her left hand raised and fingers spread apart.
Over the heads of the figures at far right arches a palm-like frond.
The green tinting of the ground beneath the figures' feet suggests grass.
Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset. A dark triangle of shadow extends from the lower right corner.
An old man, perhaps a bard, plays a large triangular harp that rests on the ground at his feet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title is a large, spiky leaf. A vine right of lines 4-11 branches into three leaves on three long stems. A vine descends in the left margin of the text and into the sky of the lower design.

component.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title is a large, spiky leaf. A vine right of lines 4-11 branches into three leaves on three long stems. A vine descends in the left margin of the text and into the sky of the lower design.

lg.l: Youth of delight come hither.
And see the opening morn,
Image of truth new-born
Doubt is fled & clouds of reason.
Dark disputes & artful teazing.
Folly is an endless maze,
Tangled roots perplex her ways,
How many have fallen there!
They stumble all night over bones of the dead
And feel they know not what but care
And wish to lead others when they should be led,

desc.objtitle:
A Dream,
Object 27 (Bentley 26, Erdman 26, Keynes 26)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The initial "A" in the title sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a loopy vine-like extension dangles all the way down the left margin. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 11) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 14). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?). In front of the tree stands a figure, robed, apparently wearing a hat, and holding a staff—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 18), the glow-worm of the text in human form. He is one of four small human figures on the plate. The other three are in the area of the title: lying, presumably sleeping, on the left stroke of the initial "A"; sitting, perhaps reading, in the "D" of "Dream"; and floating or flying, with arms raised horizontally, between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream." The animal life of the poem appears in similarly tiny forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 5) or beetle to the right of line 5 and perhaps another ant crawling beneath the "her" in line 10, a worm or caterpillar nestled in the lower right sprigs of the vegetation right of line 6, and beetles(?) (lines 20-21) flying right of lines 6 and 19. A bird, perhaps an eagle, unmentioned in the text, spreads its wings above "dream" in line 3. Faint blue background washes suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: In front of the tree in the bottom right corner stands a figure, robed, wearing a hat, and holding a staff in his(?) right hand, a lantern(?) in his left—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 18), the glow-worm of the text in human form.

There are three tiny figures in the area of the title: one lying, presumably sleeping, on the left stroke of the initial "A"; a second sitting, facing left, perhaps reading, in the "D" of "Dream"; and a barely visible third hovering or flying with arms raised horizontally between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream."

The insect life of the poem appears in tiny forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 5) or beetle crawling to the right of line 4 and perhaps another ant crawling beneath the "her" in line 10, a worm or caterpillar nestled in the lower right sprigs of the vegetation right of line 7, and perhaps beetles (lines 20-21) flying right of lines 6 and 19. The human figure lower right may be the anthropomorphic form of the "glow-worm" (line 16).
A bird, perhaps an eagle, soars just below the space between "A" and "Dream" in the title.

Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The initial "A" in the title sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a loopy vine-like extension dangles all the way down the left margin. A further extension of this vine, or an independent vine, runs horizontally below the last stanza. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 11) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 14). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?).
The watchman in the lower right corner may be holding a staff in his right hand and a second object—perhaps a lantern—in his left. He seems to be wearing a hat.
Faint blue background washes suggest sky.

lg.l: Once a dream did weave a shade.
O'er my Angel-guarded bed,
That an Emmet lost it's way,
Where on grass methought I lay,
Troubled wilderd and folorn"folorn": i.e., "forlorn".
Dark benighted travel-worn,
Over many a tangled spray,
All heart-broke I heard her say.
O my children! do they cry,
Do they hear their father sigh.
Now they look abroad to see,
Now return and weep for me.
Pitying I drop'd a tear;
But I saw a glow-worm near;
Who replied. What wailing wight
Calls the watchman of the night.
I am set to light the ground,
While the beetle goes his round:
Follow now the beetles hum,
Little wanderer hie thee home.

desc.objtitle:
On Anothers Sorrow On Another's Sorrow,
Object 28 (Bentley 27, Erdman 27, Keynes 27)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right edge of the plate. A vine grows up around its trunk; grape clusters are visible opposite stanzas 6 and 7. At the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near the bird with long tail feathers that ascends to the right of stanza 6. Other birds fly to the right of lines 7, 13, and 24; two also perch on the branch to the right of line 6 although they tend to merge with the vegetation in this copy. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. The left margin is dominated by a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree. A figure playing a pipe stands next to the right tree, lower left; he may look down at an indistinguishable object (possibly a dog as in other copies) on the ground at left. There is a second figure climbing in the branches above, opposite stanza 7. There may also be a third figure with arms raised, opposite stanzas 2 and 3, although the figure merges with the tendrils in this copy. A fourth human form, left of stanza 1, stands facing right with at least one arm raised and wears a gown. Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: There may be as many as four figures in the left margin, although only three are clearly pictured in this copy. A figure, facing left, stands at the base of the tree on the left and plays a pipe. A second figure climbs in the branches above, opposite stanza 7. A third, opposite stanzas 2 and 3, raises his arms as if in supplication—although in this copy the figure is hard to separate from the vines. The final figure, clearly represented left of stanza 1, stands facing right with at least one arm raised vertically and wears a gown.
The form to the left of the piper might be a dog, as in other copies.

A bird with long tail feathers ascends to the right of stanza 6. Three other birds fly to the right of lines 7, 13, and 24; two also perch on the branch to the right of line 6 although they tend to merge with the vegetation in this copy.

A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right margin. A vine grows up its trunk; at the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near stanza 6. The vine bears grape clusters opposite stanzas 6 and 7. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. In the left margin is a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree.
The standing figure at bottom left is playing a pipe.
Background washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Can I see anothers woe,
And not be in sorrow too.
Can I see anothers grief.
And not seek for kind relief.
Can I see a falling tear.
And not feel my sorrows share,
Can a father see his child,
Weep, nor be with sorrow fill'd.
Can a mother sit and hear.
An infant groan an infant fear__
No no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
And can he who smiles on all
Hear the wren with sorrows small.
Hear the small birds grief & care
Hear the woes that infants bear__
And not sit beside the nest
Pouring pity in their breast.
And not sit the cradle near
Weeping tear on infants tear.
And not sit both night & day.
Wiping all our tears away,
O! no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
He doth give his joy to all,
He becomes an infant small.
He becomes a man of woe
He doth feel the sorrow too.
Think not. thou canst sigh a sigh,
And thy maker is not by.
Think not, thou canst weep a tear,The last three letters of "tear" did not print clearly in copy S.
And thy maker is not near.
O! he gives to us his joy.
That our grief he may destroy
Till our grief is fled & gone
He doth sit by us and moan
